III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/8/23 youth reports that staff at the Hainley House used a
hold restraint due to youth acting out. Youth was sent to nursing
and the hospital to be evaluated on 5/16/23 where ER staff
reported youth had a left shoulder sprain and needed follow up
with an orthopedic specialist. Youth has complained of pain since
the incident. Medical reports received today indicate that youth
was seen yesterday and is now needing an MRI, physical therapy,
and cortisone shots due to a possible muscle tear which the MRI
should confirm. Medical staff also report that shoulder surgery
may be needed for the injury. Details on the actual hold/restraint
incident are unknown. Youth is currently suffering pain in his left
shoulder. Youth reports that the pain has improved about 65
percent since this initially happened, but the pain has not
completely gone away.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/4/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported he was restrained by Staff 1 in May. Youth A was kicking
the door, punching the door, and window. Staff 1 told Youth A if he
kicked the door one more time, Staff 1 would place him in a
restraint. Youth A reported he kicked the door again. Youth A was
in the hall in the corner of the building with three staff around him.
Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s arms and Staff 1 brought his knee up
and pushed his knee into Youth A’s back and took Youth A to the
ground. Youth A reported he heard a pop/crack noise in his
shoulder. Youth A told Staff 1 to let him go, Staff 1 continued to
tighten his hold. Youth A reported his “arm felt numb and broken”
after the restraint. Youth A did not recall what other staff were
present. Youth A described Staff 1 taking him to the ground as
Staff 1 having Youth A in the Benevolent hold standing behind
him, Staff 1 picked him up slightly off the ground to get Youth A’s
2

legs off the ground. Youth A reported he was sitting on his knees
in a kneeling position after Staff 1 took him to the ground. Youth A
indicated he was moving in the restraint as he thought he hit or
elbowed Staff 1 during the restraint. Youth A was inside the
school when he was restrained. Youth A denied pulling open a
locked door. Youth A reported he did open a door that was
unlocked. Youth A saw Nurse 2 after the restraint. Youth A was
given an ice pack. Youth A reported his left shoulder continued to
hurt following the restraint. Youth A reported he was not able to
lift his left arm. Youth A reported he was telling Hainley staff, no
staff specified, that his shoulder was hurting and was told he
“would go to the doctor at some point.” Youth A reported Manager
was called to the house a week later and saw the bruising and
took pictures. Youth A reported he saw Nurse 1 and was sent to
the Emergency Room (ER). Youth A reported he was seen at the
ER and referred to Orthopedics. Youth A has a MRI scheduled to
determine if he will need surgery. Youth A reported he is not able
to pick up heavy items, he is unable to lift his left arm without
shaking and wanting to lower his arm. Youth A did not have any
bruising at this time. Youth A reported he informed his mom about
the injury however had not spoken with his caseworker about the
injury. Youth A reported staff attempted to restrain him once since
the May restraint however it was unsuccessful as the staff did not
want to hurt Youth A’s arm.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
reported he was present when Youth A was restrained at the
school as Youth B reported “I was adding to the chaos.” Youth B
reported after restraints with Staff 1 he feels like he has no arms,
his arms feel numb as if his arms are asleep. Youth B reported
Staff 1 uses too much force in restraints and when other staff are
present, Staff 1 goes to those staff later and talks to them about
the restraint. Youth B reported staff support Staff 1 because other
staff are afraid of Staff 1. Youth B reported Youth A was
screaming how Staff 1 “only restrains to hurt us, you little bitch.”
When Youth A screamed this, Staff 1 pulled up on the restraint,
Youth A’s legs were off the ground and Staff 1 “dropped” Youth A
to the ground. Youth B reported he believes Youth A was
positioned on his knees on the floor in the seated restraint. Youth
B reported Youth A was moving his body during the restraint and
then stopped toward the end of the restraint as Youth A “had no
strength left.”
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/4/2023
and 8/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1
3

reported there was a school lockdown drill and Youth A was
dysregulated. Youth A was running around saying “I’m the
shooter.” Youth A was kicking and banging on windows and head-
butting windows. Youth A was yanking on doors. Staff 1 was
attempting to calm Youth A down while Staff 4 was attempting to
calm Youth B down who was also kicking and hitting windows.
Staff 1 and Staff 4 were using proximity control, which Staff 1
described as stepping in between Youth A and Youth B and the
window. Staff 4 was attempting to stand between Youth A and
Youth B as they were both kicking the same window. Youth A
was continuing to hit and kick windows and then began to head
butt the windows. Staff 1 informed Youth A that it was unsafe
behavior. Youth A went to headbutt the window again and Staff 1
intervened for Youth A’s safety and placed Youth A in a
Benevolent restraint and moved to an Aegis safety position. Staff
1 reported Youth A was caught off guard by the restraint and
described Youth A as “in shock” and Youth A immediately leaned
backwards, dropping to the ground, causing Staff 1 to transitioned
into the Aegis seated safety position. Staff 1 described this as he
took a deep step backwards. Staff 1 reported he did not fall or trip.
Staff 1 denied lifting Youth A off the ground. Staff 1 denied his
knee going into Youth A’s back. Staff 1 reported Youth A
transitioned to a seated position on his butt. Staff 1 reported it
was a short restraint as Youth A was not resisting. Staff 1 denied
tightening up on the restraint as he stated Youth A was not
resisting. Staff 1 reported once he and Youth A were in the Aegis
safety position, he released Youth A from the restraint as Youth A
stated, “I’m done” and Staff 1 could feel no tension and the safety
risk was no longer. Staff 1 reported he is a trainer in the Aegis
Model, and he completed the restraint appropriately. Youth A did
report his arm and front peck hurt however Staff 1 thought this
was from an unknown previous injury. Staff 1 reported Youth A
complained of shoulder pain however frequently complains of
shoulder pain. Staff 1 reported he did not hear a pop/crack noise
during the restraint as it was very loud during the incident as
another youth had pulled the fire alarm and youth were yelling as
they exited the school building. Youth A left the area with another
staff, Staff 1 did not recall which staff. Staff 1 did not see any
bruising on Youth A.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/4/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 was working on
5/8/2023 when Youth A was restrained however was not present
during the restraint. Staff 2 reported on 5/13/2023 Youth A was
complaining of not being able to lift his arm to put his shirt on.
Staff 2 was assisting Youth A and saw the bruising on Youth A’s
4

under upper left arm armpit area down Youth A’s side. Staff 2
believed she spoke with Manager about the bruising and Youth A
was referred to nursing. Staff 2 did not remember if Youth A
talked with her about details of the restraint. Staff 2 described the
bruising as looking like “deep bruising” that was “colorful”. Staff 2
reported Youth A complained about the pain for about a week
following the restraint. Youth A was provided with ice and pain
medication.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/4/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 was not present
on 5/8/2023 for the restraint Youth A was in however talked with
Youth A immediately after the restraint. Youth A was complaining
of shoulder pain. Staff 3 reported Youth A immediately was seen
by nursing staff and saw the doctor the next day. Staff 3 reported
Youth A was given ice by nursing and Ibuprofen. Staff 3 did see
Youth A’s shoulder however did not recall when he noticed the
bruising. Staff 3 reported Youth A did have bruising on the back
of his under-armpit area. Staff 3 did not see any bruising on
Youth A’s pectoral muscle. Youth A did not report anything about
the restraint to Staff 3. Youth A was favoring his left arm/shoulder.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/8/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 4 reported he was
present when Youth A was restrained by Staff 1 as Staff 4 was
trying to de-escalate Youth B. Staff 4 reported Youth A was
walking the halls, kicking and hitting walls and lockers, and then
began punching windows. Staff 4 reported he vaguely remembers
stepping in front of the window to prevent Youth A from punching
the glass. Staff 4 reported Youth A was restrained by Staff 1 due
to concerns of Youth A’s safety with punching windows. Youth A
was placed in a Benevolent restraint by Staff 1. Staff 1 and Youth
A fell to the ground. Staff 1 had his backpack on, and Staff 4 was
unsure if this had something to do with them falling. Staff 4
reported he believes Staff 1 and Youth A fell forward and to the
side, and was unsure how Youth A landed, however Staff 4
believed Staff 1 landed on top of Youth A. Staff 4 reported Youth
A was resisting in the restraint. Staff 4 reported he did not see
any improper techniques during the restraint and his only concern
was the fall at the beginning of the restraint. Staff 4 did not recall
what happened after the fall in the restraint. Staff 4 believed Staff
1 released Youth A from the restraint. Staff 4 reported Youth A
calmed down quickly in the restraint. Staff 4 did not have any
interaction with Youth A after the restraint as Staff 4 was working
in a different house. Youth A did not talk to Staff 4 about his
shoulder. Staff 4 reported he did not see Youth A’s bruise and
5

just learned about the bruise from Administrator. Staff 4 reported
he was not surprised about Youth A having a bruise as he
attributed the bruise to the fall in the restraint. Staff 4 did not hear
Youth A say anything during the restraint. Staff 4 thought there
was another staff present however did not know who.
Nurse 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Nurse 1
reported she did see Youth A on 5/16/2023 and filled out
paperwork for Youth A to go to the ER. Nurse 1 reported Youth A
had bruising on his left arm under his armpit and on his side and
looked in pain, so she sent him to the ER. Nurse 1 reported Youth
A was seen at the ER on 5/16/2023 and was scheduled for an
Orthopedic appointment and then a second follow up Orthopedic
appointment six weeks later for follow up. Youth A has also been
scheduled for an MRI on 8/9/2023 as well as a physical therapy
appointment. Youth A has a follow up with Orthopedic to have an
MRI 8/18/2023. Youth A has been complaining of shoulder pain
and has been given Ibuprofen and muscle rub cream.
Nurse 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Nurse 2 did not
recall exactly but thought he saw Youth A following the restraint
on 5/8/2023. Nurse 2 looked through Youth A’s file and did not
see a medical note about examining Youth A following the
restraint on 5/8/2023. Nurse 2 reported best practice is to do a
medical note following seeing a youth however it is not a required
policy/procedure. Nurse 2 did get a picture of Youth A’s bruising
sent to him by Manager on 5/13/2023. Nurse 2 reported the
bruise looked to be a deeper tissue bruise from a pulled muscle.
Nurse 2 reported in his three years’ experience at the facility,
youth do complain of arm pain following restraints as the upper
arm is above the shoulder and extended back. Nurse 2 reported
in his experience at the facility shoulder pain is not common as a
result of restraints. Nurse 2 has had two youth that required follow
up medical for shoulder injuries from restraints in the three years
he has worked at the facility.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/4/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Therapist did
not remember if Youth A talked with her about the restraint or
shoulder injury. Therapist did not remember if Youth A had
bruising or ever showed her bruising from the restraint.
Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Manager was
6

contacted on 5/13/2023 by Staff 2 to look at Youth A’s left
arm/shoulder. Youth A had bruising under his left armpit area
which Youth A reported was from a restraint. Manager took
pictures of the bruising and contacted on call nurse which was
Nurse 1. Manager texted pictures of Youth A’s bruising to Nurse
1. Manager instructed staff to do an incident report. Youth A did
not report any concerns regarding the restraint to Manager.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/4/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator 1
reported Youth A was dysregulated and was yanking on school
doors. School doors are locked from the outside and for Youth A
to pull hard enough to get in through the locked door, Youth A
would have had to pull very hard which could have caused the
injury. Administrator 1 reported Youth A has not been restrained
since 5/8/2023. Administrator 1 is a trainer in Aegis restraint holds
and demonstrated the restraint hold. Administrator 1 reported it
would be normal for a youth to get bruising under the armpit area
if the youth is resisting the restraint. Administrator 1 reported
Youth A was complaining of arm pain and was seen by medical
however there was no bruising at that time or indication or the
degree of the shoulder injury.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator 2
reported Youth A was very dysregulated on 5/8/2023. Youth A
was outside Administrator 2’s office window. Administrator 2 saw
Youth A jump onto the large air conditioning unit and pull himself
up onto the administrative/school building roof. Youth A was
yanking on locked doors.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 8/10/2023.
Complainant reported being informed of the restraint that occurred
on 5/8/2023 however was not informed of any injury because of
the restraint. Complainant became aware of Youth A’s injury per
medical reports on 8/3/2023. Complainant reported seeing Youth
A one to two times a month and Youth A did not report any injuries
or pain. Complainant receives weekly updates from the facility
regarding Youth A and there were no reports of Youth A having an
injury or being in any pain.
MDHHS worker does not have any findings in this
investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
7

• Incident Report Michigan Department of Health & Human
Services 154140204 dated 5/8/2023: Youth A was climbing
on the ventilation system outside of the school and climbed
onto the roof. Youth A climbed down and was punching the
school window. Youth A yanked the school door open and
went inside the school and was yelling “help he’s going to
kill me” as he ran toward a classroom. Youth A was yelling
“It’s a shooter out here.” Youth A kicked the window,
headbutted the window, and punched the window. Staff 4
stood in front of the window and Youth A pushed Staff 4
and continued hitting the window. Staff 1 stood in front of
the window and Youth A pushed Staff 1 out of the way.
Staff tried to redirect Youth A from the unsafe behaviors.
Youth A continued to kick and punch the window. Staff 1
placed Youth A in a Benevolent restraint. Youth A dropped
his body weight to the ground transitioning the restraint to
an Aegis safety position. The restraint lasted 1 minute.
Youth A had complaints about his shoulder and was taken
to nursing. Nursing cleared Youth A and gave him pain
relief medication and an ice pack. No other follow-up was
needed.
• Eagle Village Incident Report dated 5/13/2023: Staff 2
asked Youth A about the bruise. Youth A reported the
bruise was from a restraint a week prior by Staff 1. Staff 2
viewed the bruise that was “really large” on Youth A’s left
pectoral that extended to under his left armpit. Youth A
also had a large bruise that ran along the back of Youth A’s
upper left arm. Manager came and viewed the bruise and
took photos. Youth A reported he noticed the bruise on
5/10/2023 and had been seen by nursing.
• Spectrum Health Emergency Room documentation dated
5/16/2023: Youth A was seen for shoulder pain. Youth A
reported left shoulder pain and bruising following a restraint
at Eagle Village six days ago. Diagnosis: chest wall
contusion, left, initial encounter and sprain of left should,
unspecified should sprain type, initial encounter. Follow up
recommendations to follow up with primary care provider or
orthopedic doctor.
• Spectrum Health Orthopedics Sports Medicine Office visit
documentation dated 8/2/2023: Youth A reports continued
shoulder pain and feels he lacks range of motion and
endurance. Treatment Plan: Get MRI to rule out a surgical
tear. Start physical therapy as a corticosteroid injection
8

and physical therapy may be adequate if Youth A has a
small labral tear. Physical therapy evaluation and treat.
• Spectrum Health Hospital Blodgett MRI Imaging Result
Report for Youth A dated 8/9/2023: Anteroinferior labral
tear with mild medialization of the labroligamentous
structures and additional suspected nondisplaced tear of
the posteroinferior labrum. Separation of the
anterosuperior labrum from the glenoid could relate to be
pathological tear/detachment or related to re-existing sub
labral foramen.
• Corewell Health Big Rapids Hospital Orthopedics After Visit
Summary for Youth A dated 8/18/2023: Youth A referred for
an EMG for injured nerve in shoulder. Youth A has a tear
in the labrum that will need to be repaired via surgery
following the EMG results. Youth A is to remain in physical
therapy.
• MDHHS worker MiSACWIS social work contact on
8/18/2023 with Doctor: Youth A has a torn nerve and will
need surgery and continued physical therapy. The MDHHS
worker described the scenario of the restraint which was
the same Youth A explained it to the Doctor. The injury
was a result of the restraint and would be an expected
injury when a youth is resisting a restraint. This injury would
not have required excessive force to occur and can simply
be caused by a youth attempting to get out of a restraint.
There are no concerns of abuse.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures for Therapeutic Holds: 1 to 1 Benevolent
Restraint is the only single staff intervention hold Aegis
identifies as an appropriate one to one intervention. This
position can either be utilized as a standing positioned or
where the youth is lowered to the seated position slowly
and the youth’s torso is positioned perpendicular with the
floor.
• Staff 1 and Staff 4’s personnel file: Staff 1 has one
disciplinary record for an unwarranted restraint dated
3/9/2021. Staff 4 has no disciplinary record. Staff 1 and
Staff 4 completed the required Aegis training on 2/8/2023.
Staff 1 completed the Aegis Instructor training on
11/3/2022.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as based on interviews with
staff, youth, and medical documentation review, the restraint was
9

preformed correctly, and the injury is commonly seen in youth who
resist during restraints. There was varying information reported in
staff and youth interviews however the restraint occurred on
5/8/2023 and this investigation did not come in until almost three
months after, resulting in a lengthy timeframe in recalling the
incident. Medical findings and report from Doctor indicated there
was no concern of excessive force causing the injury and it is a
consistent injury with a youth resisting a restraint.
CONSULTATION:
It was recommended to the facility a procedure be implemented
for anytime a youth is seen by the facilities medical staff that
documentation occur. It was recommended to the facility to ensure
communication of medical concerns/appointments be
communicated with the referring worker in order to keep the
referring worker informed of what is occurring with the youth. It is
recommended the agency review shoulder injuries youth report
following restraints to determine if there is a pattern and if Aegis
model restraint techniques need to be reevaluated.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy.
It is recommended that the current license status be continued.
